content.question:
Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

An important economic indicator is the labor participation rate. The labor participation rate is the proportion of the population of people <math alttext="16" overflow="scroll"><mn>16</mn></math> years and older that are working or actively looking for work. Dr. Ogden, an economist, believes this proportion for a certain city increased from January <math alttext="2022" overflow="scroll"><mn>2022</mn></math> to December <math alttext="2022" overflow="scroll"><mn>2022</mn></math>. A random sample of people <math alttext="16" overflow="scroll"><mn>16</mn></math> years and older from that city was taken in January <math alttext="2022" overflow="scroll"><mn>2022</mn></math> and an independent random sample of people <math alttext="16" overflow="scroll"><mn>16</mn></math> years and older from that city was taken in December <math alttext="2022" overflow="scroll"><mn>2022</mn></math>. The sample outcomes are shown in the table.

January <math alttext="2022" overflow="scroll"><mn>2022</mn></math>

December <math alttext="2022" overflow="scroll"><mn>2022</mn></math>

Working or actively looking for work
<math alttext="55" overflow="scroll"><mn>55</mn></math>
<math alttext="35" overflow="scroll"><mn>35</mn></math>

NOT working or actively looking for work
<math alttext="50" overflow="scroll"><mn>50</mn></math>
<math alttext="15" overflow="scroll"><mn>15</mn></math>

(a) Consider the data in the table.
(i) What proportion of people who were sampled in January <math alttext="2022" overflow="scroll"><mn>2022</mn></math> were working or actively looking for work?

frqParts.text:
Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

An important economic indicator is the labor participation rate. The labor participation rate is the proportion of the population of people <math alttext="16" overflow="scroll"><mn>16</mn></math> years and older that are working or actively looking for work. Dr. Ogden, an economist, believes this proportion for a certain city increased from January <math alttext="2022" overflow="scroll"><mn>2022</mn></math> to December <math alttext="2022" overflow="scroll"><mn>2022</mn></math>. A random sample of people <math alttext="16" overflow="scroll"><mn>16</mn></math> years and older from that city was taken in January <math alttext="2022" overflow="scroll"><mn>2022</mn></math> and an independent random sample of people <math alttext="16" overflow="scroll"><mn>16</mn></math> years and older from that city was taken in December <math alttext="2022" overflow="scroll"><mn>2022</mn></math>. The sample outcomes are shown in the table.

January <math alttext="2022" overflow="scroll"><mn>2022</mn></math>

December <math alttext="2022" overflow="scroll"><mn>2022</mn></math>

Working or actively looking for work
<math alttext="55" overflow="scroll"><mn>55</mn></math>
<math alttext="35" overflow="scroll"><mn>35</mn></math>

NOT working or actively looking for work
<math alttext="50" overflow="scroll"><mn>50</mn></math>
<math alttext="15" overflow="scroll"><mn>15</mn></math>

(a) Consider the data in the table.
(i) What proportion of people who were sampled in January <math alttext="2022" overflow="scroll"><mn>2022</mn></math> were working or actively looking for work?
(ii) What proportion of people who were sampled in December <math alttext="2022" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2022</mn></math> were working or actively looking for work?
(b) Complete the mosaic plot for these data.

Recall that Dr. Ogden believes the true proportion of people <math alttext="16" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>16</mn></math> years and older from the city that were working or actively looking for work increased from January <math alttext="2022" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2022</mn></math> to December <math alttext="2022" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2022</mn></math>. To test this belief, Dr. Ogden will conduct a two-sample <math alttext="z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>z</mi></math>-test for a difference in population proportions. Assume all conditions for inference have been met.
(c) Let <math alttext="p sub J" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>p</mi><mi>J</mi></msub></math> represent the true proportion of people <math alttext="16" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>16</mn></math> years and older from that city that were working or actively looking for work in January <math alttext="2022" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2022</mn></math> and <math alttext="p sub D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>p</mi><mi>D</mi></msub></math> represent the true proportion of people <math alttext="16" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>16</mn></math> years and older from that city that were working or actively looking for work in December <math alttext="2022" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2022</mn></math>.
(i) What are the appropriate hypotheses for Dr. Ogden’s test?

(ii) The <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>p</mi></math>-value of this test is <math alttext="p equals 0.019" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>p</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.019</mn></math>. What conclusion should Dr. Ogden make at the <math alttext="alpha equals 0.05" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>α</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.05</mn></math> level of significance?

topic.text: 1.3: Representing a Categorical Variable with Tables

skill.text: Skill 1.F: Identify null and alternative hypotheses.
